rename.to: issue: Watch don't work with React Compiler (React 19)

body: Since React Compiler is still experimental, the bug have also been reported to React Compiler team, they replied it works as excepted and the library don't follow the React guidelines : https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/29144

issue.title: allow react 19 peer dependency

labels.name: waiting-up-vote
labels.description: Waiting for votes from the community.

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: request a feature to be added

repository.name: react-hook-form
repository.description: ðŸ“‹ React Hooks for form state management and validation (Web + React Native)

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
NextJS 15 RC depends on react 19, would be great to not cause peer dependency issues by upgrading

**Describe the solution you'd like**
looser semver, check that the library still works properly (#11910 types of issues exist so maybe docs need update too)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
waiting until it's stable?

**Additional context**
this is separate from actual API improvements to make RE #11832

body:
@Maxou44 thanks for reporting this here! For folks working on react-hook-form, we've written up some guidelines for how to think about designing libraries for maximum compatibility with React, including React Compiler.

As @bluebill1049 notes, using `useMemo` with `watch` will cause results to be stale. This is part of a pattern, where non-hook APIs should always be memoizable. We cover this in https://github.com/reactwg/react-compiler/discussions/10 ("Any non-hook usage of your library should be memoize-able" section). Please let us know if you have questions!
thanks for the comment @josephsavona, is there a way we can flag the compiler to skip the memo within the library to avoid the potential breaking change?

I guess ["use no memo"](https://react.dev/learn/react-compiler#use-no-memo) can be used temporarily?
Currently trying to wrangler with [Shadcn Form](https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/form), RHF and the compiler. Looks like memoization in RHF is the main issue, not sure though

The challenge is that _callers_ of the API would need to skip compilation. For your library itself you could just not compile the library - thatâ€™s your choice! But developers are going to expect that their libraries donâ€™t block them from adopting the compiler on their own code. 

Ultimately the watch API would need to either change (so that the form object itself changes when its state changes) or be replaced w the useWatch() API.

> For your library itself you could just not compile the library - thatâ€™s your choice! 

Could you give some more details on this? We should probably do this before introducing breaking change.

What I mean is that you can choose whether to apply React Compiler to the code that you publish. 

Regardless, though, your _users_ might wrap a call to watch() in a useMemo() (always allowed in React) or use React Compiler, which will do the equivalent of wrapping watch() calls in useMemo, and that will break their apps. 

Note that useWatch is compatible w useMemo and React Compiler, so it seems like you should be able to deprecate watch in favor of useWatch. Unless thereâ€™s something Iâ€™m missing! This is all just a heads up so that you have context on potential issues your users may face using the library.
thanks, @josephsavona makes sense. I will seek a solution if possible without deprecating `watch`. It's a great API for DX.
If we put the watch function in a useState, and update it each time a value is changed, it should work, no ?

> If we put the watch function in a useState, and update it each time a value is changed, it should work, no ? `return
{watch('test)}
` should work just fine.

issue.title: Tracking React 19

repository.name: nv-rental-clone
repository.description: Navotar with Tailwind and Tanstack Router and Query

issue.body:
Tracking anything currently that I think needs some resolution before I can ship React 19. ## Tracking matrix | Project | Comments | Issue(s) | PR(s) | |--------|--------|--------|--------| | ~Radix-UI~ | ~Breaking~ | ~https://github.com/radix-ui/primitives/issues/2769~
~https://github.com/radix-ui/primitives/issues/2933~ | ~https://github.com/radix-ui/primitives/pull/2934~ | | Recharts | Breaking | https://github.com/recharts/recharts/issues/4558 | N/A | | Cmdk | Installation peer-dep warning | https://github.com/pacocoursey/cmdk/issues/266 | N/A | | ~React Hook Form~ | ~Installation peer-dep warning~ | ~https://github.com/react-hook-form/react-hook-form/issues/11932~ | ~https://github.com/react-hook-form/react-hook-form/pull/11935~ | | ~React Hook Form~ | ~Breaking~ | ~https://github.com/react-hook-form/react-hook-form/issues/11910~ | ~[`useWatch`](https://react-hook-form.com/docs/usewatch)~ | Basically, I need something relatively not too buggy before I move over (like a `beta` or `rc`). ## Comments *Just whatever comments I have regarding the tracking process here.* ### âœ… radix-ui - ~React 19 support is being tracked in the open PR.~ - ~The branch has been merged in and released as a 'release candidate' under the `next` tag (`-rc.4`).~ - Radix has pushed the changes to main. ### ðŸš¨ recharts - React 19 support is being tested in the releases tagged under `alpha`. ### ðŸš¨ cmdk - The packages uses primitives by radix-ui, so it can be expected that React 19 support should follow soon after the Radix PR goes through. ### âœ… react-hook-form - ~The `form.watch` doesn't work when the react-compiler is turned on, unless you memorize the watcher with an eslint ignore.~ ```tsx const form_checkoutDate = React.useMemo( () => form.watch("checkoutDate"), // eslint-disable-next-line react-compiler/react-compiler // eslint-disable-next-line react-hooks/exhaustive-deps [form.watch("checkoutDate")] ); ``` - The workaround is to use the [`useWatch`](https://react-hook-form.com/docs/usewatch) hook to not have to trick the react-compiler using `useMemo`.
